The real past is fine and using memory is extremely useful. The error is believing that the "me" who exists in the memory is yourself. 

What we are actually trying to do is recognize the concept of "me" to be completely nonsensical and useless.
@nymandus66 this may be relevant

i found that to be true as well, definitions tend to get changed slightly to fit non-dualism better
like "love" to a non-dualist is completely different from most people because what most people think is "love" is actually just ego in disguise

A more precise way of describing it is not in terms of a "me" but just that there exists sensory perception, which is all that exists subjectively. Whether then decide to refer to the entirety of the sense perception as "me" is completely arbitrary since the sense perception is just what it is. 

There's no relationship between me and sensory perception. It's just one thing which is sensory perception now.

In this sentence it still appears that the "me" is treated as something that exists for a duration. You were not there to experience it is because you only exist literally right now experiencing the memory. 

The false "me" (the self-image) that appears exist for a duration is composed of only memories. What's really happening is a character is invented based on the memories, and then the memories look like they relate to the character, so the relationship looks like a "me relating to memories" when in fact it is just memories relating to memories with no me anywhere in that structure.

I suppose I was approaching the concept of "me" as necessarily being related to one's own experience by definition. I figured it makes no sense to say that something has a personal relationship to yourself if you have absolutely no personal experience regarding it.

My point was just that different sensations occur in different places so you can tell they are different. To be fair that is hard to see, but it becomes much easier to see after meditation. 

Seeing and thinking about seeing are fundamentally different even if they don't seem like it. 

I am of the opinion that mediation would help you (and probably most people) more than any conversation you could possibly have on this server, but of course you don't have to take me up on that

The sensation of touch is in your foot
The thought is in your head
You can tell this is true the moment you stop thinking because the sensation in your foot is still there

dreams are still entirely composed of thought, it just becomes much much harder to realize that during a dream. thoughts are very good at pretending to be other things, thats sort of their whole thing

it can help to notice that all perception of thinking has a spatial location in relation with your body: sort of behind the eyes between the ears, like there is no thinking going on in your foot. recognizing the locations of each sense perception makes it far easier to differentiate between them

this is a bit of a weird example: when you think there might be someone behind you, it feels like there is almost like a *feeling* going on behind you, but whats actually happening is thinking reconstructs a mini model of what it believes your entire environment is, there is a *feeling* that happens in your head, but behind the mini-version of you inside of the model, and then physically in real life you turn around. this whole thing becomes a lot easier to discern through meditation rather than just reading and thinking about it. *part of that is the ability to step outside of your own thinking*
Yeah makes sense thanks

They are separate streams of information
If you had a tv with 6 channels, each for one sense perception, it would never make more sense to say "one of the channels describes the others" as opposed to just there are 6 channels
You will be able to answer that question for yourself far more effectively than I can answer it for you
I don't know, I just know that I don't have experience of any past moments so nothing in the past can be related to me

its not rejecting thinking, its giving thinking the same level of acceptance as every other sense

when i say "vision doesn't describe hearing" you would say "yeah obviously"
but if i say "thought doesnt describe hearing" for some reason that feels different, even though that claim is literally the exact same as the previous one

SR is not a truth claim about the way things are. SR is the end of adding narratives to your direct experience. That makes it fundamentally different from any other unprovable claim about the nature of your experience. 

To understand what I'm talking about, it is necessary to recognize thinking as merely another sensory perception

yeah it tends to be like that

from my understanding, it takes a lot of work to hammer away at the cognitive dissonance for any of the self-inquiry stuff to *feel* true rather than just acknowledging it as an intellectual argument

for me the most effective thing was to analyze emotional reactions while they were happening because its a more direct way of confronting the cognitive dissonance

The point I was trying to get at is you have no experience of the past at all, and you will never experience the future. Your actual experience is of literally exactly a singular blip *right now* and of absolutely nothing else ever. The misunderstanding is believing that your experience somehow extends to past blips and to future blips, when those don't exist at all to you. 

If you can acknowledge it as philosophically valid then why do you not fully accept it? Is that not just cognitive dissonance?

its not that im a human claiming that im not a human. there just wasn't an independent entity called a human in the first place

There are a few different approaches. Here I am not giving you answers, but more like pointers

Try sitting down closing your eyes as if you were about to meditate. In that moment what is the thing convincing you that you are the body?

Consider the following:
Scenario 1: Pikachu and Pikachu's friend switch bodies. *Despite being in the body of Pikachu's friend, you are the one harboring Pikachu's crush because you have Pikachu's memories. Your friend (in Pikachu's body) goes and says a bunch of embarrassing things to your crush in your body and you feel super embarrassed. *
Scenario 2: In an alternate universe you and your friend were born in each other's places, so you are living Pikachu's friend's life in his body and Pikachu's friend is living Pikachu's life in Pikachu's body. Essentially, imagine that you are your friend. Then suddenly you both switch memories. *Despite being in the body of Pikachu's friend, you are now the one harboring Pikachu's crush because you have Pikachu's memories. Your friend (in Pikachu's body) goes and says a bunch of embarrassing things to your crush in your body and you feel super embarrassed. *

Is there a difference between the two above scenarios? Where is the embarrassment actually coming from? When you think about "my life" and "my sense of self", how did you become "yourself" in the first place? What is staying the same about yourself when you imagine yourself to be switching bodies? 

Sorry if the 2 scenarios are confusing. I tried to write it as clearly as I could but I still think it's not very clearly written.

I agree that stuff has happened before. I'm not disputing that at all. 

Experience of time is so important because the root of the self-image is in a misunderstanding of one's relationship with time. Put very simply: You believe the entity who had experience of the past *is actually yourself*. Since you can think about that past entity you believe you can think about yourself. 

However, it is not the case that you were really there to experience the past (this is what the alien analogy is talking about), so it makes no sense to identify with memory (all thoughts are just memories dressed in different clothing). It is of paramount importance to very closely examine what your relationship with time actually is, because that is the root of the misunderstanding which gives rise to self-image in the first place. Your actual relationship with time is absolutely non-existent. The true nature of your experience is absolutely instantaneous with no duration, but there are thoughts that can very convincingly masquerade as an experience of the past or as duration. 

Put another way: *You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now... You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now... You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now... You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now... You have suddenly been placed in this body with all of its functions and memories right now... *

@pikachu_is_boss question for you which i also asked creikey

If you believe SR to be impossible for yourself do you still pursue it?

SR is not the perfection of living life. SR is realizing there is nothing other than living life, so no matter what you do you cannot fail to live life. As Jamie put it: "It is literally impossible to fuck up being yourself." To be fair when Jamie says that he's not referring to being a a dad or a lawyer or some other social identity as the thing you cannot fuck up as. He is referring to your mere existence as consciousness, *which is itself what you are*, as something that cannot fuck up at anything. 

What makes SR valuable to you? I would imagine that it only seems valuable to someone who has suffering they wish to escape from. I would say that if you haven't already, inquire into the mere fact that you feel you cannot stop pursuing SR, because that structure is your self-image.

I don't say this to prove a point this is just a question for you to ask yourself: Are you able to directly observe the truth of your own statements in your own experience or do you only understand your own statements as being statements? @lucahs. @creikey 
Y'all seem to talk about the brain a lot. Thinking about neurons and synaptic plasticity is not useful at all for self-inquiry. All the answers to self-inquiry exist in your own direct experience *and only your direct experience*. Although if self-inquiry is not what you're using neuroscience for then just carry on. However, I would caution you against making conclusions about SR using neuroscience. Especially because mainstream neuroscience has never made any claims about the nature of SR. Current neuroscience isn't able to understand SR at all.

I mean the alien could be a shapeshifter. I dunno. That wasn't the point though. The point is that the alien also has all your memories of what you believe is "your body". He can claim about the haircut "you" got last weekend "yeah I remember being there when I got that haircut! I was really there!" to the exact same extent that you can. 

I suppose once you exit the machine the analogy breaks down. Let's try a different version of the analogy: The alien uses the machine to only download your memories from the last day. The alien then goes "dang I've had such a crazy time in the last day as a human lol" and then leaves you to go off and collect another day of human experience for him to download from you. After you've exited the machine you come back a day later and then the alien uses the machine again to download your memories. Each day he feels his memory bank of human experience expanding. 

Is the alien's relationship with "your memories" of those days at all different from your own? What I am saying is that your own relationship with "your memories" is fundamentally no different from the alien's relationship with "your memories", so ownership over a memory in the first place makes no sense. 

Where to go from there? Your self-image is based on memories which you believe are about "me". The point of all of this alien memory business is to see that the concept of "this memory is about me" is in itself complete nonsense. No matter what memories you have it makes no sense to personally identify as the subject of the memory. In theory, fully understanding the point of the analogy ends any identification with thought because it is seen that there is no "me" in memory who can be thought about. Memory is just another sensory perception occurring *now*.

the central point im trying to get at is this:
the entire self-image is fundamentally based on memory. You believe that memory is actually what you experienced in the past. I'm saying that is wrong. It makes absolutely no sense at all to ever claim "yeah it was really me who experienced that in the past, and this memory proves it".

Here is Jamie's alien analogy: "I think a good way to point to our misunderstanding of our relationship with time is to imagine there’s an alien who wants to experience what it’s like to be a human. The alien takes you and plugs some wires into your brain and says, I’m going to take over your consciousness for a second to download your memory. Ok close your eyes, and in 10 seconds I’m going to take over. Ok 3 2 1 I’m opening my eyes as a human for the first time. Huh, weird. feet huh?” and they swap back having downloaded the data and the alien says thanks, I understand you now. You might say “what, that’s it? How can you know what it’s like to be me, I had to go through years of self-improvement to get where I am now. I was bullied in school and had two terrible relationships before figuring out who I am now” “yeah I know it was in your memory” “what no, it took like half my life to go through that” “yeah dude I was literally you I know” “no but you can’t know what it was like you didn’t experience it you just sat there, what does it feel like for someone to break up with you?” “Feels bad man” “what, but it didn’t happen to you” “bro, I was literally you. I knew exactly what you know now. It’s in your memories” “what, but. You didn’t… you weren’t there”."

Does any identification with a memory make sense if the alien could always claim "nonono that was me there, that wasn't actually you?" What would make your argument for really being there stronger than the alien's?

Imagine that you're a kid whose default state of existence is not wanting ice cream, because that's how most kids are. Most kids aren't actively thinking about ice cream all the time (as far as I can tell). Most days on your walk home from school with your mom you don't have any reason to think about ice cream, and then you don't have any ice cream, and you get home and everything is alright. Then one day walking home from school with Mom you see an ice cream truck and really want ice cream from it. Then it leaves before you have a chance to buy an ice cream and now you're devastated. 

Your direct experience on most days is not eating ice cream. Your direct experience on that day was not eating ice cream. It is the exact same. You're not dissatisfied because you didn't get ice cream, you're dissatisfied because you compared your present scenario with a "better" imaginary scenario of getting ice cream. The mind is an asshole and selectively makes comparisons to "better" imaginary scenarios way more often than "worse" imaginary scenarios, even though that comparison is not more valid than any other comparison. Why not compare the fateful day of missing the ice cream truck with any other normal day when you walk home from school and don't get ice cream? 

The same concept applies to comparison in general: Why does someone with body dysmorphia compare their body to someone who they believe has an attractive body far more than they compare their body to unattractive bodies? 

TLDR: the mind makes selective comparisons that often lead to suffering; paying attention to those comparisons and making different strategic comparisons can alleviate some, if not all of the suffering from comparison

Since SR, the only emotional reactions I've had are a bodily tension in response to an event happening right then, or a sense of shame from believing I hurt someone. Yes these are still fundamentally emotional reactions due to belief, if you consider that sense of heightened tension an emotion. Is it a separate mechanism? I have no idea. I would guess that it's the same mechanism but just used differently. Maybe negative emotional reactions to thought would be an unnecessary hijacking of the mechanism. The negativeness feeling of a negative emotion does seem to be something entirely different though.

Emotional reactions are manifestations of psychological belief as physical sensation. I'm referring to the belief causing the emotional reaction as the "origin".

What I meant in that message is that whenever I had an emotional reaction I could always come up with a reasonable sounding intellectual explanation for what belief was tied to that emotion.

well at first i didnt know exactly what i had realized. It just made absolutely no sense to be able to think about yourself. When you see things you see vision. When you think thoughts you think about thoughts. Vision can't contain you, vision is just vision. Thoughts are literally the exact same. That's how the realization initially manifested. But that realization only came when I could really *feel* that there is no perception of time at all. Then it becomes easy to grasp that you can't think about yourself, essentially for the reason that the alien analogy attempts to communicate. 

Seeing through time and seeing through memory are the same thing. The way that you understand time *is through memory*.

I've always been interested in the mind and perception and psychology so I would always have questions for myself about why I believed certain things

I've got a strange question which very well could lead nowhere. 

Do you feel you have a strong understanding of what beliefs compose your self image? When you have what you consider irrational emotional reactions, do you more or less immediately know what belief is tied to that emotion? 

I've begun to wonder whether SR necessarily requires a very strong intuitive grasp of one's self-image before the self-image can even be properly examined in the first place. After all, how can you examine who you think you are if you don't even know who you think you are? That would make all of our talk about sledgehammers and aliens and time sort of a moot point if we don't first deeply understand what we already believe.

Here is Jamie's alien analogy: "I think a good way to point to our misunderstanding of our relationship with time is to imagine there’s an alien who wants to experience what it’s like to be a human. The alien takes you and plugs some wires into your brain and says, I’m going to take over your consciousness for a second to download your memory. Ok close your eyes, and in 10 seconds I’m going to take over. Ok 3 2 1 I’m opening my eyes as a human for the first time. Huh, weird. feet huh?” and they swap back having downloaded the data and the alien says thanks, I understand you now. You might say “what, that’s it? How can you know what it’s like to be me, I had to go through years of self-improvement to get where I am now. I was bullied in school and had two terrible relationships before figuring out who I am now” “yeah I know it was in your memory” “what no, it took like half my life to go through that” “yeah dude I was literally you I know” “no but you can’t know what it was like you didn’t experience it you just sat there, what does it feel like for someone to break up with you?” “Feels bad man” “what, but it didn’t happen to you” “bro, I was literally you. I knew exactly what you know now. It’s in your memories” “what, but. You didn’t… you weren’t there”."

Does any identification with a memory make sense if the alien could always claim "nonono that was me there, that wasn't actually you?" What would make your argument for really being there stronger than the alien's?

I think at that point the discussion gets a little too abstract and we confuse ourselves over whether there is a difference between a completely intangible property-less observer versus no observer at all.

I'll elaborate. 

Thoughts: Sit still for 1 minute and don't think about orange penguins. Don't visualize their orange bellies. Can you do it?
Wants/Preferences: Make yourself stop wanting something. Literally change your desires. Start liking a food you've always hated. Can you do it? 
Actions: This one is trickier. Is there any action you take that isn't related to a desire? If there isn't, then did you really have ultimate control over that action?

Like imagine that you're not actually you. You're someone else living in J41R's body with all the thoughts and memories of J41R's mind. The only difference between this scenario and your actual experience is the belief that your self knowledge is not actually related to you. Would your ability to navigate the world be any different? 

Going deeper, how did you become J41R in the first place?

I'm not sure whether there wouldn't be a feeling of tension because it sounds like a situation that requires immediate action. 

You have knowledge about what you think is yourself, but that is just knowledge. The self-image is the belief that these bits of knowledge actually represent something about "me." The knowledge itself is quite useful but the belief that it has something to do with "me" serves no utility.

A funny thing about this analogy is that it's permanently renewing. 
*You started existing right "now" and have been suddenly placed in this body with all of its memories and functions... You started existing right "now" and have been suddenly placed in this body with all of its memories and functions... You started existing right "now" and have been suddenly placed in this body with all of its memories and functions...*
You can never hold onto the past

I'm not saying the events didn't happen. I'm saying the person who experienced the events wasn't you. You only know the memory which occurs right now. 
> My body knows, not just my mind
That would be part of the body's functions that you inherited when you were placed in it right now. The body knows but the body isn't you. Since the body knows, the body will continue to enjoy the relationship with the siblings regardless of the continuity of *your* experience.

Honestly? Not sure. I believe the concept of "actual physical stuff" to be complete nonsense.

What would it even mean for the ultimate reality to be physical
If there is an object, once you try to describe it with enough specificity it always becomes a description of actions and properties (like quark "spin" and electron "repulsion"). It seems like the ultimate "stuff" must be more related to behavior than to any sort of matter. 

At the deepest level it seems like nonsense to even say that physical things exist outside of their behavior. All that actually exists is the behavior and properties.
If that is a property of nonphysical things, then it seems reasonable to say that consciousness must be nonphysical. How could you actually test if another person is conscious?

Is the feeling of seeing blue that is indescribable to a blind person physical? 

That direct experience, which is fundamentally not the same thing as the neural correlate, is a nonphysical phenomenon.

Materialism 
All things are in some way ultimately physical

Panpsychism is interesting too. It's an attempt to get around the hard problem of consciousness by flipping the whole thing over and saying that matter comes from consciousness and consciousness is fundamental.

There's a theory that the brain is more like a radio that tunes into or funnels consciousness rather than creating it. 

This is a theory popular among people who are looking for an explanation for memories of past lives and weird near death experiences. I think it's more plausible than it sounds. The belief that all phenomena have a physical underpinning is really just scientific dogma.

I guess it depends on how pedantic you are with the limitations of mental abstraction

When you say, "I would like to no longer believe it is possible to think about myself then", that is an attempt to think about yourself. Desire for self-realization is itself part of the false belief structure that ceases after self-realization.

When you say "I genuinely want self realization", that is just a thought that occurs right now. That image has nothing to do with you. Even when self-realization happens, nothing about "me" changes at all. The only thing that changes is a belief structure. There is no such thing as "being self-realized". There is only the belief that it is possible/not possible to think about yourself. 

I think that the disagreement here is mostly about whether being interested in the image in your mind about "self-realization" counts as *actually being interested in self-realization*.
waddaya think? (i havent watched it, im wondering whether it seems worth watching)

When you see SR as something to attain, that's *is itself* an image of a "me" who is becoming something in the "future". SR isn't a process of becoming something. It's a sudden realization that beliefs about a "me" are an incoherent concept, and always have been an incoherent concept. 

SR is not something you become. It's merely a belief that is dropped.

1. It was shortly after I gave up on thinking that pursuing SR actively was worth it, that the realization happened. I suspect that's not a coincidence.

Functionally, memory *does* represent something about the past. However, experientially it has nothing do with the past. When you recall a memory about a past event, that is its own sensory experience occurring *now*. 

You're right that it's useful in the purpose it serves, but your *experience* of time is not of duration. It is of exactly *right now*. You do not exist as an entity across time. You exist *right now*. 

In regards with SR, memory serves the same function that it always has. The only difference is that there is no longer a recognition of a "me" who exists in memory recall. It is all just sensory experience happening *now*.

You cannot compare two experiences because comparison is itself the experience. The belief that you can compare multiple experiences comes from the belief that your memories actually have a real relationship with the past. Memories are merely thoughts that occur *now*. 

Essentially, in terms of your experience, *it's all one bro*. 

I'm sure that there are other misunderstandings that are actually the same. If you stretch it hard enough, literally every single misunderstanding we talk about in this server is all part of the same structure of "an image of 'me' who exists across time".
Yeah. Awareness of awareness isn't possible. In the same way that the eye cannot see itself.

I don't actually know where direct insight really comes from. Meditation may help. More inquiry may help. I dunno.

It's worth noting that misunderstanding of comparison and misunderstanding of time are the same misunderstanding.

Having a construct of a "me" is absolutely very useful when navigating social situations. However, mistaking the construct for literally being "me" causes a lot of unnecessary suffering. It's not that having a construct is unnecessary, but literally recognizing a "me" inside of that construct is unnecessary. You are not the construct. You are the awareness of sensory perception. Supposing that you were to be "socially rejected", it would still just be awareness sensory perception. The actual nature of your true identity never changes throughout that whole process.

Experience cannot be compared. 

When you try to compare one experience with another, that *is itself* an experience. Comparison is just an experience in itself without a real relationship with previous experiences. The content of the previous experiences are entirely contained within that present experience. 

The more fundamental misunderstanding has to do with time. Your experience occurs exactly right "now". 

The one diagram I made and posted in the discussion forum, happens to literally be exactly on this topic. Perception of time is the crux of the SR phenomenon: <#1408808608233295892>

Inquiry into your own direct experience of time is probably the only way to clarify the misunderstanding. It's a direct insight, not something you can logic through.

SR is the realization that it isn't possible to acknowledge yourself as the organism because the only thing that you could try to "acknowledge yourself as" is a false image of you, not what you really are. 

So I guess from a certain point of view you're kind of right.

My answer is going to seem very unsatisfying. 

The fact that an organism claims it experiences qualia has literally nothing to do with whether it actually does. The qualia being referred to by the word "qualia" has nothing to do with qualia itself. It is just a thought. There are plenty of organisms that you would probably say are conscious, who cannot claim they are conscious, and plenty of AI systems that can claim they are conscious without actually being a conscious agent. 

I think the weirdness of this answer has to do with not believing in free will. It all eventually goes down a far deeper rabbit hole that probably goes beyond the topic of SR.

its hard to talk about this stuff because the whole problem is that there isnt actually a way to talk about a "me" that isnt just a thought

I'll try to clarify. 

The only thing that exists is sensory perception and the awareness of it. The observer is itself the awareness, and nothing else. My day to day experience of seeing things and making decisions is more or less the exact same as someone who believes they have authorship of their actions. I don't experience a state of complete detachment from the world because the sensory experience I'm aware of is of the world. The only experiential difference is that when I recall memories, I don't perceive a "me" related to any of it. 

There isn't a sense of a "me" getting carried around. There's just sensory perception of the world, which includes thinking. The observer can't actually observe itself, it can only see the TV. The observer not being able to observe itself is analogous to "you can't think about yourself". SR is not a permanent state of feeling helplessly stuck inside of the body of some character, it's realizing that there never was a "me" that could be stuck in the body in the first place. Awareness isn't stuck inside of the body, it sort of just is. 

While you're reading this, what's happening is just the contents on the TV changing. Any attempt to understand the totality of what's on the TV or the observer is also just the contents of the TV changing. The experience of SR is also just contents of the TV changing to no longer try to display who the observer is, because it's seen to be impossible. The observer is never actually affected by any of the contents of the TV. 

To really understand what I mean, you have to drop the TV analogy entirely and inquire directly into your own experience. See that the way the analogy describes your perception is actually how your perception functions. Ultimately, the analogies are just a bunch of words that appeared on the TV. 

Feel like that was confusing. If something needs clarification feel free to ask.

I'll try to clarify what "intellectual" means. It's not intellectual because the "answer" doesn't present itself as a thought that gets labeled as the answer. SR is a thoughtless insight into the nature of one's own perception. In the same way that realizing that thoughts are kind of like a voice in your head that you don't really have control over is sort of a feeling instead of a thought, SR doesn't present itself in the form of a thought.

I'm not sure if this is an English clarity thing but in response to the first line: Whether or not there is thinking, it is still true that all that exists to you is consciousness. 

In response to human beings as a useful abstraction: What actually is your direct experience of your "whole life"? Understanding that there is no real continuity of "me" across time is itself the crux of the phenomenon. Sure, the form of a human being and the human brain are absolutely related to how your consciousness manifests, but don't you sort of have a hidden premise from the start that you must be a human being?

Given that the self is the entirety of conscious experience, there is nothing within consciousness that isn't the self. Nothing else can be recognized like the self in a non thinking way because there is nothing else to recognize. As for how recognizing the self works? No one really knows how to cause it consistently, but meditation is known to vastly increase the chances of both temporary and permanent ego dissolution. It could be something worth trying if you haven't already. There unfortunately isn't a purely intellectual way "road to SR"  because SR is not an intellectual realization. 

Just my 2 cents: I think inquiring into your experience of time may be beneficial. Jamie says time is the crux of the phenomenon.

I think that the concept we're talking about is slightly different from feeling the pain in the past. It's the lack of continuity in the first place.

In the case of the movie being likened to literally the entirety of one's own perception, as you watch the movie, you will receive all the normal stuff like vision and audio from the outside world, but somewhere in the corner there's a small program trying to string together what all the past frames of the movie looked like. That is the self-image stringing all those past "me" 's together. It is imperative to understand that this little program itself exists within the current frame of the movie. When that is understood, it becomes intuitively obvious that even though that program in the corner is trying to represent past frames, it is still just part of the present frame, so it makes no sense to actually believe that this part of the screen represents something about what the past frames really were. Ultimately it's still *just* the present frame. 

Ig this is another version of Jamie's TV and signal analogy. I'm trying to communicate the same thing here. The little program in the corner is analogous to his thinking channel.

Suppose you change your sledgehammer scenario such that it's someone else getting attacked by a sledgehammer, and you're the one meant to defend them. Here you are in the present moment anticipating that a sledgehammer may hurt someone else in the future, which is totally reasonable, so then you act to try to protect them. However, it would not be reasonable to say that you are the person who was directly threatened by the sledgehammer. 

Here it is intuitively obvious that it's not you threatened by the sledgehammer, but even in the case where the sledgehammer appears to be about to hit you, it's still not threatening "you", it's threatening a future person, who as of right then, only exists as an image in your mind. 

The fundamental misunderstanding is that there is no true continuity of "me" at all. Every new moment is a new person who exists right now. The mistake is to compile all of these images together of past "me" 's and then try to say that this entire structure is "me". Sure it describes something and is of incredible utility, but that story is not "me". "Me" is only right now.

MB I misconstrued what you said a little. Maybe it would be better for me to have said, "All that you experience is experience." 

About the rest of what you said: The false belief is not that there is no body and no past or something like that. That belief is fine. The fallacy is in personal identification with the body (and any thought based identification in general). You are not your body, in the same way that you are not the car you are currently driving. I think this is what Jamie was trying to communicate with the Mario analogy. It's not that Mario doesn't exist. It's that there is no actual separation between Mario and the video game. In the same way that Mario is part of the video game, you are a part of the world, not separate from it. 

There is this old Eastern teaching that I found helpful: You are not your mind. Rephrasing it, there is literally no difference between someone telling you something, and thinking something to yourself. Both cases are an observation of a thought from a source that is not you. Realizing that you are not the one generating the thoughts makes self-inquiry far easier.

This may surprise you but I don't believe that physical stuff is the most fundamental *stuff* of the universe. I believe that consciousness is the most fundamental *stuff*. This is a view called panpsychism. 

It's not directly related to SR, but rather tangentially related.

Well all the beliefs exist within your mind in some form. It's probably just that thinking by itself is not a particularly effective way to gauge beliefs. It's certainly useful but not very powerful just on its own.

Yeah it's a tricky thing. I suspect that beliefs themselves aren't actually a thing that can be reasonably thought about. 

Eckhart Tolle mentions in one of his books that when inquiring into one's own beliefs, physical emotional sensations are always representative of what you really believe as opposed to the thoughts that are attempting to bandage it over. I don't know if that gets at the nature of belief itself at all but it could be a start.
Okay... So then why do you believe it to be so self evident that you must be a physical body if all there is is experience?

Okay maybe what I was suggesting in the last message was a bit too radical. I think it's fair to accept that physical things exist. However, I don't think it's fair to accept that you experience physicalness, which is more precisely the belief I'm suggesting that you question. What causes you to conclude that you experience physical things?

Just my 2 cents but this seems like a belief definitely worth questioning. How do you even know that physical things exist? What does physical even mean? There are a lot of underlying assumptions in this statement that aren't provable but you start it with "the fact of that matter is".

I have no problem with the idea that we are human organisms progressing through time, but my claim is that you don't experience that progression through time at all, and it is that *perceived* progression through time that causes you to identify with your thoughts.
Hope this helps

The misconception is not in the nature of thought but rather in the nature of time. 

Your memories are what cause you to conclude that there is a you that exists external to your present perception. When the recollection of memories are recognized to also occur in the present moment, then the personal identification with thought ends automatically. 

I think you're right to question whether "you can't think about yourself because you're a thought" is useful to say because it doesn't really get anyone anywhere.
